data.title: 144 years on from George Herbert Bailey’s odyssey, Tasmania finally gets its day (night) in the Ashes sun (moonlight)
data.meta_description: Welcome to Ashes cricket, Tasmania. Frankly, you should have been here years ago. And ironically, what got you the Test is the force that for so long held you b
data.text:
Welcome to Ashes cricket, Tasmania. Frankly, you should have been here years ago. And ironically, what got you the Test is the force that for so long held you back — isolation, which in the age of Covid, is now a boon.

Albeit that you should have had a day Test rather than another made-for-television evening matinee, this is a proud moment for you. Imagine had it been Tim Paine’s farewell Test as well. At least take some solace from the Australian team having been picked by a local patriot, that excellent man George John Bailey.

Could it have been otherwise? Could Ashes cricket have crossed Bass Strait earlier? After all, Launceston hosted this Australia’s inaugural first-class match (1850-1), Tasmania hosted two of the pre-Test
